citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is an approximately 3 week old female Boston Terrier puppy that is observed to be much smaller than its litter
mate. The puppy is observed to have thick, opaque white discharge on the right eye and she was not holding the eye
open all the way. She also has a very large head, a continuous head tremor, open, red, raw sores on her hind paws, and
was not walking nearly as well as her litter mate. The inspectors observed the litter mate frequently step on this puppy.
The licensee had the Attending Veterinarian (AV) examine this puppy on 23-Febuary-2023 and the licensee was
instructed to monitor her. APHIS officials spoke to the AV and they report that they did instruct the licensee to monitor the
puppy. She also reports that the puppy did not have discharge from the right eye, nor did it have sores on the paws when
examined on 23-February-2023. The AV notes that last week, when the puppies were 2 weeks old, it was harder to tell
how much behind the puppy was from her litter mate as they were not very mobile yet. The licensee has noticed that the
puppy was much smaller than the litter mate and had not contacted the AV regarding the changes in this puppy’s health
including the tremors, feet sores and lack of overall improvement. Daily observation of dogs is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior and well-being is conveyed to the AV with direct and frequent
communication. Failure to convey accurately the status of the puppy to the AV may result in delay in treatment and
possible pain and distress. Correct by ensuring that daily observations, especially if worsening of a condition is noted, is
conveyed to the AV in a timely manner. Correct by having a licensed veterinarian assess the Boston Terrier puppy and
maintain records of treatment for APHIS inspection.
To be corrected by: This dog was taken to the AV during inspection for evaluation and treatment.
A male Shih Tzu (microchip # 933000320069010) has significant matting at the inside corners of his eyes, so much so
that the inspectors could not readily see his eyes. This dog is also seen to have a significant build up of hard, brown
material on right upper cheek teeth and the gum tissue is pulled back from the tooth roots on right upper cheek teeth.
When examined by the inspectors, the two upper right cheek teeth were loose. The licensee attempted to shave the dog’s
face during the inspection and accidently cut the skin below the left eye creating a large, flapping, red, open wound. Daily
observation of all dogs is required. Failure to observe the dogs for matting and dental issues can cause a delay in
conveyance of information to the AV regarding the animals’ health, behavior, and well-being. Correct by ensuring that
daily observations are made to check the hair coat, teeth, ears, and eyes of the dogs and by having a licensed
veterinarian assess the male Shih Tzu listed above and maintain records of treatment for APHIS inspection.
Correct by: This dog was taken to the AV during inspection for evaluation and treatment.
The inspector’s identified a dead puppy underneath the elevated enclosures in the adult side of the kennel. The licensee
reports that a female Bichon (microchip # 933000320452590) was moved from that enclosure to the whelping side of the
facility that morning because he saw what he thought was blood. The licensee had not noticed the puppy on the floor. He
did state that he didn’t think she was close to whelping yet. The female Bichon was noted to have dark green-black dried
discharge on her hair on the back legs and around her vulva. Her abdomen was tense when palpated by the inspector
and was not observed to have active contractions. Daily observations of all dogs to assess changes in their health and
well-being is required so that accurate and timely conveyance of information can be given to the AV. Failure to observe
and convey a change in a dog’s health or behavior could cause injury, illness, pain, or distress. Correct by ensuring that
changes in the dogs are reported to a veterinarian and have a licensed veterinarian assess the female Bichon listed
above and maintain records of treatment for APHIS inspection.
Correct by: This dog was taken to the AV during inspection for evaluation and treatment.
A Bichon (microchip # 7E10315344) has excessively long toenails and had dried, crusty, and opaque yellow-green
discharge from the left eye. The licensee was not aware of the eye discharge and had not contacted the AV at the time of
inspection. Daily observation of all dogs is required to accurately and timely diagnose diseases and injuries that may
cause pain or distress to the dog. Correct by conducting adequate daily observations and having frequent and direct
communication with the AV concerning any medical issues. The Bichon listed above must be evaluated by a licensed
veterinarian and maintain records of treatment for APHIS inspection.
To be corrected by: End of business 1-March-2023.
A Bichon (microchip # 933000320069011) is matted throughout the body’s haircoat, has long front toenails and has poor
dental health. There is an excessive build up of hard, brown-grey material on all the teeth. The gum tissue of the upper
left side of the mouth is recessed away from the tooth roots of the upper cheek teeth and at least 2 upper cheek teeth
were loose when examined by the inspector. The licensee was not aware of the poor dental health, they did acknowledge
this dog needed to be groomed and have a nail trim but they have not had time to complete spring grooming. Daily
observation of all dogs is required to accurately and timely diagnose diseases and injuries that may cause pain or distress
to the dog. Correct by conducting adequate daily observations and having frequent and direct communication with the AV
concerning any medical issues. The Bichon listed above must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian and maintain
records of treatment for APHIS inspection.
To be corrected by: End of business 1-March-2023
A female chocolate Cocker Spaniel (microchip # 933041000045168) has severe matting on the legs, ears, and face. The
mats are so thick and close to the skin on the legs, ears and face that the skin cannot be seen. Her belly and sides were
matted to a lesser degree and not close to the skin. The toenails are very long as well and an accumulation of brown
organic material is present in both ears. The licensee did acknowledge this dog needed to be groomed and have a nail
trim but they have not had time to complete spring grooming. Daily observation of dogs is required. Failure to observe the
dogs for matting and long toenails can cause a delay in conveyance of information to the AV regarding the animals’
health, behavior, and well-being. Correct by ensuring that daily observations are made to check the hair coat, teeth, nails,
ears, and eyes and by grooming the above mentioned Cocker Spaniel, have a licensed veterinarian evaluate this dog and
maintain medical record of treatment for APHIS inspection.
To be corrected: End of business 1-March-2023

The facility uses cage cards as the form of identification for puppies under 16 weeks of age but has not created cage
cards with the required identification information for 3 litters of puppies. An additional litter of puppies has a cage card, but
it only includes the dam’s information. Official identification is necessary for APHIS officials to be able to properly identify
animals for inspection and to trace their movements. The licensee must assign an official identification number to each of
these dogs and any future dogs born at the facility in timely manner after their birth.
To be corrected by: 6-March-2023.

A wire primary enclosure housing 2 adult bichons was in disrepair. The licensee uses metal hog rings to secure the wire
panels together. The left side wall has become disconnected from the flooring creating an approximate 1-inch by 14-inch
gap. This gap creates a risk of injury to the dogs housed within as it is large enough for a foot or leg to fall through.
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be in good
repair and protect the animal from injury. The facility must repair this enclosure so that it is safe for the dogs housed
within, the licensee was shown this enclosure during the inspection.
To be corrected by: 2-March-2023.

During the inspection, the inspectors could smell an obvious ammonia odor in the adult side of the kennel housing
approximately 104 adult dogs. The licensee states he cleans the excreta from under the elevated enclosures once to
twice a week and knows it needed to be done as it has been several days. The licensee was working on the cleaning
mechanism the morning of the inspection. Dogs exposed to excessive ammonia odor may result in respiratory diseases
and other disease hazards.
Indoor housing facilities for dogs must be sufficiently ventilated at all times when dogs are present to provide for their
health and well-being, and to minimize odors, drafts, ammonia levels and moisture condensation. The licensee must
ensure the indoor facilities are adequately ventilated and the ammonia odor does not persist.
To be corrected by: 3-March-2023.

The Program of Veterinary Care states that the licensee must test “2 adult dogs for heartworm disease and 5% of the
adults pooled in groups of 3-5 for intestinal parasites.” The licensee has not had this testing completed at the time of
inspection. Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in
writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian and includes sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests.
Sampling of dogs for parasites is necessary to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. The licensee
must have at least 2 adults tested for heartworm disease and 5% of adults tested for intestinal parasites and have records
available for APHIS inspection.
To be corrected by: 21-March-2023.

The licensee is not keeping records of Distemper/Parvovirus/Hepatitis/Bordetella vaccine being administered to adult
dogs. The Program of Veterinary Care instructs these vaccines be done annually, the licensee states this is done at the
beginning of the year but doesn’t write it down.
The lack of medical records, particularly vaccine records, makes it difficult to determine if the animals are receiving
vaccines to protect them against potentially deadly and contagious diseases. Dealers must keep copies of medical
records and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These records must include the names of all vaccines and
treatments administered and the dates of administration.
To be corrected by: 6-March-2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Lauren Murphy, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There is an approximately 3 week old female Boston Terrier puppy that is observed to be much smaller than its litter 
mate. The puppy is observed to have thick, opaque white discharge on the right eye and she was not holding the eye

puppy was much smaller than the litter mate and had not contacted the AV regarding the changes in this puppy’s health 
including the tremors, feet sores and lack of overall improvement.  Daily observation of dogs is required so that timely and

possible pain and distress. Correct by ensuring that daily observations, especially if worsening of a condition is noted, is

maintain records of treatment for APHIS inspection.

Correct by: This dog was taken to the AV during inspection for evaluation and treatment.

Correct by: This dog was taken to the AV during inspection for evaluation and treatment.  
 
A Bichon (microchip # 7E10315344) has excessively long toenails and had dried, crusty, and opaque yellow-green 
discharge from the left eye. The licensee was not aware of the eye discharge and had not contacted the AV at the time of

cause pain or distress to the dog. Correct by conducting adequate daily observations and having frequent and direct 
communication with the AV concerning any medical issues. The Bichon listed above must be evaluated by a licensed 
veterinarian and maintain records of treatment for APHIS inspection. 
To be corrected by: End of business 1-March-2023. 
 
A Bichon (microchip # 933000320069011) is matted throughout the body’s haircoat, has long front toenails and has poor 
dental health. There is an excessive build up of hard, brown-grey material on all the teeth.  The gum tissue of the upper 
left side of the mouth is recessed away from the tooth roots of the upper cheek teeth and at least 2 upper cheek teeth

this dog needed to be groomed and have a nail trim but they have not had time to complete spring grooming. Daily

concerning any medical issues. The Bichon listed above must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian and maintain 
records of treatment for APHIS inspection. 
To be corrected by: End of business 1-March-2023

A female chocolate Cocker Spaniel (microchip # 933041000045168) has severe matting on the legs, ears, and face. The 
mats are so thick and close to the skin on the legs, ears and face that the skin cannot be seen. Her belly and sides were

organic material is present in both ears. The licensee did acknowledge this dog needed to be groomed and have a nail

ears, and eyes and by grooming the above mentioned Cocker Spaniel, have a licensed veterinarian evaluate this dog and 
maintain medical record of treatment for APHIS inspection. 
To be corrected: End of business 1-March-2023 
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The facility uses cage cards as the form of identification for puppies under 16 weeks of age but has not created cage 
cards with the required identification information for 3 litters of puppies. An additional litter of puppies has a cage card, but 
it only includes the dam’s information.  Official identification is necessary for APHIS officials to be able to properly identify 
animals for inspection and to trace their movements. The licensee must assign an official identification number to each of 
these dogs and any future dogs born at the facility in timely manner after their birth. 
 
To be corrected by: 6-March-2023. 
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general.

A wire primary enclosure housing 2 adult bichons was in disrepair. The licensee uses metal hog rings to secure the wire 
panels together. The left side wall has become disconnected from the flooring creating an approximate 1-inch by 14-inch 
gap. This gap creates a risk of injury to the dogs housed within as it is large enough for a foot or leg to fall through. 
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be in good 
repair and protect the animal from injury. The facility must repair this enclosure so that it is safe for the dogs housed 
within, the licensee was shown this enclosure during the inspection. 
 
To be corrected by: 2-March-2023. 
3.2(b) 
   
Indoor housing facilities. 
During the inspection, the inspectors could smell an obvious ammonia odor in the adult side of the kennel housing 
approximately 104 adult dogs. The licensee states he cleans the excreta from under the elevated enclosures once to 
twice a week and knows it needed to be done as it has been several days. The licensee was working on the cleaning 
mechanism the morning of the inspection. Dogs exposed to excessive ammonia odor may result in respiratory diseases 
and other disease hazards. 
 
Indoor housing facilities for dogs must be sufficiently ventilated at all times when dogs are present to provide for their 
health and well-being, and to minimize odors, drafts, ammonia levels and moisture condensation. The licensee must 
ensure the indoor facilities are adequately ventilated and the ammonia odor does not persist. 
 
To be corrected by: 3-March-2023. 
3.13(a)(3)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care states that the licensee must test “2 adult dogs for heartworm disease and 5% of the 
adults pooled in groups of 3-5 for intestinal parasites.” The licensee has not had this testing completed at the time of 
inspection. Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in 
writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian and includes sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests. 
Sampling of dogs for parasites is necessary to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. The licensee 
must have at least 2 adults tested for heartworm disease and 5% of adults tested for intestinal parasites and have records 
available for APHIS inspection. 
To be corrected by: 21-March-2023. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not keeping records of Distemper/Parvovirus/Hepatitis/Bordetella vaccine being administered to adult 
dogs. The Program of Veterinary Care instructs these vaccines be done annually, the licensee states this is done at the 
beginning of the year but doesn’t write it down. 
 
The lack of medical records, particularly vaccine records, makes it difficult to determine if the animals are receiving 
vaccines to protect them against potentially deadly and contagious diseases. Dealers must keep copies of medical 
records and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These records must include the names of all vaccines and 
treatments administered and the dates of administration.  
 
To be corrected by: 6-March-2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
Lauren Murphy, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section
